text: ep.io provides WSGI hosting Heroku style.
It's from Andrew Godwin of South fame.
From their website:
They support PostgreSQL and Redis.
They have a client you download to deploy from the command line, or you can push to them via git or mercurial.
They have a good amount of documentation, but I just recently started using them and haven't pushed a deployment yet so I have no idea of how well the service works yet.

Heroku itself is now for Django, too!
Sort of.
:) Heroku now implicitly supports Django with its new Cedar "run anything" release.
See:

http://news.ycombinator.com/item?id=2612943 and
http://news.heroku.com/news_releases/heroku-announces-major-new-version-celadon-cedar-includes-new-process-model-full-nodejs-
Its not automated like Rails and Node.js would be, so you'll have to be pretty smart with your configuration skills.
But you if you can follow this:
http://www.askthepony.com/blog/2011/07/getting-django-on-heroku-prancing-8-times-faster/
it should get you there and beyond.
Update:
Heroku is starting to document its support for python & django.See:

http://blog.heroku.com/archives/2011/9/28/python_and_django/
http://devcenter.heroku.com/articles/django
Djangy seems to be similar.
I used neither, so I can't say how similar they are.
Djangy only supports MySQL as a database, which is kind of a deal breaker for me.
